text: is a common dilemma in the enterprise; it comes when deciding between developing a tool internally or buying it from someone else.

text: a term used when a company uses the same products they produce; Microsoft employees using Word is an example of "dogfooding"

text: it is an acronym for "for your information"; used in email to tell the reader that a given email is ust informative and does not need to be replied to.

text: "Looks Good To Me" is a phrase commonly used to indicate that a code integration can go ahead. For example, in a merge request.
author: fferegrino

text: "Out-Of-The-Box" is a phrase commonly used to describe the default features included in a library or language.
author: fferegrino

text: it is just an acronym for "paid time off"

text: When talking about platforms like GitHub or GitLab, both Pull Request and Merge Request refer to the same action: a request to integrate code from one branch o another.
author: fferegrino

text: is a term used to refer to the code created by code generation tools that help us when creating a new app. For example, yeoman is a scaffolding generator tool.
author: fferegrino

text: is a term used to refer to the code created by code generation tools that help us when creating a new app. For example, yeoman is a scaffolding generator tool.
author: fferegrino

text: an acronym for "too long; didn't read" commonly used to give a short summary of a larger piece of text
author: fernandzad

text: is a term used to refer to software in its purest form. For example, when someone says they did something in "vanilla JavaScript", it means they didn't use any framework.
author: fferegrino

text: The term "FANG" refers to the name of these four popular American technology companies: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Google
author: israteneda

text: OOTO is an acronym that means “Out of the Office.”
